entry.title: The Secret to Successful Team Growth
entry.content:
Teams are the future of the real estate industry, but teams aren't always the best route. If your team doesn't grow the right way, the money won't justify it.

Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518)861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Real estate teams are the overwhelming trend in modern real estate, and everybody seems to love them. There is, however, a dirty little secret about real estate teams that I wanted to myth-bust. The myth is that a bigger real estate team is better.

Recently, I saw a post by someone I have a lot of respect for who has built a large team that said, “I was making more money when it was just me and two assistants.” I can say that I've been fortunate to grow a great team and that my income has grown every year with the growth of our team.

“
Many teams fall into a trap of growing too quickly and having expenses exceed revenue.
”

However, many teams get pulled into a trap of growing too quickly and having expenses exceed their revenue. At the end of the day, we get pulled into the trap of letting our egos go. It doesn't matter if you sell 4 million homes or gross $200 million—what matters is what you net.

When you build a team, you have to do it systematically.

I'm always asked who the first team member should hire is. I did it wrong by first hiring a buyer's agent. Your first hire should be an assistant. Think of it this way: if you don't have an assistant, you are the assistant, and you're doing $10 an hour tasks. Once you have a great assistant, you can grow a team slowly and systematically. Then, you can bring on a showing agent to take some of that buyer stress and extra work away from you.

If you hire two buyer's agents and two assistants, I absolutely guarantee you that you'll be more profitable than many of the teams out there who sell many more homes than you do—their expenses get out of control, yours don't.

I'm actually trying to get my guys to build teams within my teams, and it's pretty cool to watch.

If you're interested in how I built my team and how we've grown net revenue every year, give me a call. We have a spot open right now for a buyer's agent who wants to make $150,000 in 2017!

link.title: The Secret to Successful Team Growth

entry.title: How to Adapt in an Ever-Changing Industry
entry.content:
In an ever-shifting industry, the agent of the future is someone who can convert Internet leads and pair them with good old-fashioned customer service.

Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518)861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

What does the agent of the future look like? 

In the old days, real estate was done differently than it is now. Agents used to send out postcards with pictures of homes that were just sold or just listed, and all transactions were done face to face in places like clubs or churches. 

Now, larger corporations are taking over the industry, and 96% of buyers start their home search online by hitting sites like Zillow, Trulia, or Realtor.com. Those leads then get sold back to us. The Internet is generating the leads. 


“



Larger corporations are taking over the industry.
”


Even if people have a great friend or know somebody in the business, the Internet is where they’re starting their search. They don’t even know which agent will be contacting them. Farming neighborhoods takes a very long time, so it's important to find a new way to adapt to the quickly moving market.

Millennials are starting to buy homes in bulk, but how do you reach them if they never open their mail? You need to get them on the Internet. 

The agent of the future is someone who can use new technology to convert internet leads and makes sure to always exhibit stellar customer service. The agent of the future can give instant follow up to those buyers who are combing Zillow on their iPhones and pair it with the ability to give the client a great experience. These days, that can only really be done with a team. You can’t be there for someone all the time, but a team can.

In our office, for example, the slogan ‘Clients First’ is brandished everywhere—in our bathrooms, our kitchen, over everyone’s desk, etc. Nothing is more important than our clients. They’re why we’re in the business. We place them ahead of our own needs. That’s what a team does.

If you have any questions or want to know how you can join us, give me a call or send me an email. I hope you have an absolutely awesome day.

link.title: How to Adapt in an Ever-Changing Industry

entry.title: How to Manage Your Clients
entry.content:
All the top agents in the real estate industry have one thing in common: they control their clients instead of letting their clients control them. How is this done, though?

 Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518)861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Want to know something I’ve learned over the years about this industry? All the top agents have one thing in common: they control their clients rather than let their clients control them. By taking control, they’re being proactive instead of reactive. 

Top agents “drive the train.” By that I mean they don’t let their clients dictate to them. Instead, they give them guidance from their own experience and let them make a decision. That’s what the clients are paying them for.  

It’s important to manage the expectations of your client instead of jumping to them. This, of course, is easier if you have an abundance of clients; if you do, pick only the best ones. It’s not your job to be a chauffeur and show a buyer a hundred homes. Your job is to find a buyer a home that is suitable for them and let them live the American dream. If they have to look at 50 homes to do that, you’re doing something wrong.


“
If you have to show 50 homes to the same buyer, you’re doing something wrong.

”


The average person looks at seven or eight homes before making an offer. My agents try to cut that number down to four or five. They accomplish this through coaching and preparation. What happens when you don’t do these things? I put my own house up for sale a few weeks ago and got an offer the first day for $25,000 under the listing price. When I asked the buyer agent why this was, he told me that that was what his buyer wanted him to do. 

That’s absurd! That agent should’ve told his buyer that that kind of offer was going to alienate the seller—me—because that’s exactly what happened. You should be prepared for a scenario like that. Have a script if you have to, for instance, and use it to tell your buyer why it’s a mistake to come in at such a low value. 

Time and time again, I see deals fall apart because agents aren’t controlling the transaction and giving their clients good advice. They’re not driving the train; they’re letting their clients do that. In my opinion, real estate is a great business, but you have to control it. As an agent, you have to be in a position of power. Be honest and direct with your clients and tell them the things that they need to hear.

If you have any questions on how my agents only show four homes, give me a call or shoot me an email. I look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: Why Your Database Is Key to Your Success in Real Estate
entry.content:
This is why I believe that learning to utilize my database has been the key to my success.

Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com

I'm often asked what led to my success. 

I really haven't been in real estate full-time that long; I was an appraiser in a past life and I sold real estate part-time before doing it full-time. I was really lucky when I started out years ago selling a few homes a year from my bedroom when I came in contact with a guy named Steve Kantor, who runs Best Agent Business. 

He really instilled in me how important it is to have a database.

He's an expert on databases and got me going. I think I used Top Producer for two years before I put anything in there because it was too complicated for me at the time and I was just too busy. Now, though, I have become a database fanatic. Everything we get goes into our database. We constantly contact and touch our database; 30% of our business comes from referrals.

I just looked at my database and I've got more than 23,000 people with email addresses and phone numbers in my database. That database (not all 23,000) gets touched with direct mail newsletters, postcards, invites to our client events, and two monthly video emails geared toward consumers. 

My thought today is that if you are starting out, no matter what level you are at, get a database. 


“
No matter what level you are at, get a database.
”



Top Producer, for example, has been around for many years and it's very easy to use. You have many options. The important thing is that every lead you have, every client you close a deal with, and every person you meet needs to go into that database so you can reach them in a meaningful way. I absolutely guarantee you that if you create a database and feed it weekly, your business will flourish.

 Real estate is a contact sport. The more people you contact, the more successful you're going to be. If you need help with your database or you want to know how we utilize it and bring in leads from multiple sources, give me a call. I want you to experience success in this business.

link.title: Why Your Database Is Key to Your Success in Real Estate

entry.title: Take Your Photo Off of Your Business Card
entry.content:
Are you like the 95% of agents in the industry putting your photo on our business card? I have a cautionary tale that might make you think twice about using your photo in your marketing.

Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com

Today I wanted to talk about your business card. Is your photo on it?

I recently caught a story about a Realtor in Texas who was killed by someone she showed a vacant house to. It was tragic and unfortunate, but it's something we can learn from. 

It turns out that the killer had been looking for agents that he found attractive and found vacant listings that they had. He'd say he was a cash buyer and ask them to show him their vacant property, and this was where he committed his crimes. Before he killed this woman, there were up to 40 agents that he had made feel uncomfortable in some way with this scheme.

So my question to you is this: are you putting your photo on your business card? If so, why? Are you getting more business because your photo is on your business card? Probably not. We're the only industry as a whole where most of us put our photo on our cards, and for the most part, those photos can be 10 or 15 years old!

The upside really isn't there, because you're probably not getting more business because of it. The downside, however, is that you may stick your card up at a diner and have some nutjob, like the one who killed that woman, call you based only on your photo. That's why my agents and I are moving away from using their photo on their cards. 


“
You're probably not getting more business from the picture on your card.
”



I've become a brand based on advertising that we're doing but using your photo on a card just doesn't make sense. The same goes for ads on places like Zillow and Trulia. In fact, my top agent is making $200,000 a year and her photo isn't anywhere.

The second question I wanted to ask today is what is the biggest thing holding you back in your career? Why aren't you meeting your goals?

I think a major reason that many people share is the fear of rejection. We all want to be liked. We all want to be liked by everyone, but the reality is that no matter what you do, there are going to be clients who don't like you. You're going to deal with rejection.

The sooner you deal with that desire to be liked by everyone and can deal with rejection, the more successful you're going to be. We may be having a ton of success this year, but we've also had failures. We've lost listings that I wanted, but we've also succeeded many times. We focus on our successes, not our failures. 

Is that what's keeping you from door knocking or making 100 prospecting calls a day? Sure, people will hang up on you, tell you no, swear at you, and tell you never to call them again, but many people will also say yes. Those are the people you want to find.

In my office, we do call nights every two weeks. We order pizza and have a lot of fun in the office calling prospects. Sure, we laugh off the rejections, but the person who gets the most rejections and makes the most calls is also my highest-earning agent. He has more rejections, but he also hears 'yes' a lot more. 

There's a great book called Rejection Proof that I highly recommend. If you read this book and can improve how you deal with rejection, I guarantee your career will take off. 

 If you're still having problems, I'd love to sit down with you for a cup of coffee and share some ideas and tell you about our team. Give me a call and let's talk soon!

link.title: Take Your Photo Off of Your Business Card

entry.title: The Difference Between You and Other Agents
entry.content:
As a real estate agent, it is incredibly important to have a strong value proposition in order to win listings and help clients. What sets you apart from other agents?

Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com

Today, I want you to ask yourself a few questions. What sets you apart? What is your unique selling proposition? What is your value proposition to your clients?

I went on a listing appointment today for a home that has been listed on the market for four years. That’s right—four years. This home has been through 10 different agents. As an industry, we have failed the client. The home was listed at $1.8 million five years ago; today, it is only listed at $495,000 and still hasn't sold. We have failed at valuing the property, marketing the property, and we have failed that client. Those other 10 agents should not have taken that property on if they couldn’t sell it.

I left the home trying to decide whether or not to take the listing, which will expire next week. Right away, the owner called me and said, “Please, please sell my home. Take the listing next week before it expires because I am going to get 30 calls from agents and they are all the same.”

Think about that. She has been through 10 expired listings, and she knows what happens. She knows she is going to get 30 calls from agents trying to take that listing. But when she said, “All agents are the same,” it was very, very disappointing. Clearly, these agents are doing a very poor job marketing themselves and showing their value proposition.

Why did she come to me? We do a very good job selling our value propositions. We say, “Hey, if we don’t sell your house, I’m going to buy it.” That’s just one example of our value propositions. We also try to show how much we care for our clients and show them success stories.

If you’re an agent and you call that house again because it’s expired, you need to explain how that house is going to sell. You can’t just dump it on the market and forget about it; you have to prove your value to the client. This particular client made fun of our industry; she has talked to many agents who come in with drones and all kinds of toys. While these agents might sound great, they don’t sell homes.

If you want to win listings and help clients, you need a very solid value proposition. That Guaranteed Sold program is just one pillar of our marketing that sets us apart. Going forward, if you want to be successful, you need to differentiate yourself from other agents. Don’t just dump expired listings back on the market and forget about the client. You need to do an in-depth analysis on the property and create value for the client. Have a solid value proposition so they call you first.

If you need help differentiating yourself from other agents, just give me a call. I would be happy to talk with you and figure things out. Also, we are hiring, and everyone on my team is going to the Bahamas this year. If you are interested in working with us, just reach out to me. I look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: The Difference Between You and Other Agents

entry.title: Focusing on the Right People to Grow Your Business
entry.content:
Today I wanted to talk about growing your business. Too often, we talk about buying our way to success; a new contact management system, a new lead system. Sometimes the growth in your business is not a 'what' but a 'who.'


“
The key to growth is not a question of 'what,' it's a question of 'who.'
”


I look back at my business and my success and see that I've been joined by some really great and successful people, and without them, I likely would have failed. I took almost the entire month of July off and we still have 82 homes pending, and our business is still flourishing. That's because I have great people. When you go from a job as a Realtor to a business owner, your first hire is going to be a great assistant, not a buyer's agent.

The key is to surround yourself with like-minded people who dream big and take care of them. I'm taking my team and their spouses to the Bahamas, for example. The trip will be on me because I appreciate all they do and how dedicated they are.

Another good example comes from a recent run-in I had with a former chairman of Churchill Downs who had just sold a 700-acre horse farm. Part of the deal, he said, was that if the new owner kept all of the farm workers employed, he'd keep 50 mares there. He could've sold the farm and walked away not caring about his people, but he didn't - he made sure they were taken care of.

The key to success as you grow your business is surrounding yourself with great people. Who can you surround yourself with to move from having a job into a growing a business?

I hope you found this topic interesting and helpful. If you have any more questions about growing your business or you're interested in joining our team, give me a call or send me an email. I would love to hear from you!

entry.title: The Top Reasons Real Estate Deals Fall Through
entry.content:
I think one of the worst things that happens in real estate today is when a deal falls through. There is nothing worse than putting hours and hours into a deal and having it fall apart for a silly reason, like an unreasonable buyer or seller. This happened to me just last week.

One thing I've noticed in more than 20 years of selling homes is that newer agents tend to let attorneys negotiate structural issues. In my opinion, there is nothing worse than an agent who turns the negotiations over to an attorney. I personally have a full-time negotiator and I occasionally step in when I have to, but we never let the attorneys negotiate the structural issues.

“
Nothing is worse than an attorney negotiating structural issues.
”

Last week, I had a $225,000 transaction fall apart for a silly $2,900 repair because the attorney was demanding the repair be made before closing, even though my seller was offering a $2,900 credit. There are a couple reasons you don't want to have the seller do repairs before closing.
The first is that my sellers, for example, are going to go to the lowest-cost contractor to make that repair. My buyer generally won't have a warranty or any sort of relationship with that contractor if something goes wrong down the road.

On the flip side, if the buyer gets a credit verified by multiple estimates, you're protected, and the buyer can work with the contractor that they want to use. The reason my deal fell apart was because the attorneys were unreasonable.

We had another deal that had a delayed closing because our seller didn't have all the items removed from their house. We take the blame for that, and it could have been easily covered with a $500 return of escrow, but the attorney wanted $25,000, which is completely unreasonable.
There's no easier way to keep your commission than to breathe life back into a deal as an agent. Put your time and effort into keeping your current deals alive, and please do not let the attorneys negotiate them!
We close about 95% of our deals, and the 5% that fall through usually have an attorney negotiating. I love attorneys and they serve a great purpose, but usually the attorneys who cause deals to fall through aren't even real estate attorneys.

If you have any questions for me or you're interested in the opening I have for a buyer's agent, give me a call or send me an email. I look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: The Top Reasons Real Estate Deals Fall Through

entry.title: How To Win Multiple Offer Situations for Your Buyer
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com

We’re in a great market right now and we’re seeing multiple offers and great activity on nearly all listings. However, if you’re a buyer’s agent and you’re presenting offers in a multiple-offer situation, this particular real estate climate can make it quite difficult. So the question for today is, how do you get your buyer’s offer accepted?

I see different strategies taken by buyer’s agents, but I can tell you as a listing agent that the offers that stand out to me are the ones that are complete. By “complete” I mean they have copies of the deposit check, the pre-approval letter, and everything else (attorney approval, loan amount, type of loan, etc.) completed and filled out correctly in a reasonable time period.


“
Make sure your buyer’s offer is the complete package.
”


When you’re filling out the attorney approval, it can often take some time before the buyer signs the contract. Instead of putting a hard date on the attorney approval, then, write in “within three business days.” That way it doesn’t matter when the seller signs the contract - both sides have three business days to get to their attorneys. This will save you a lot of time from potentially needing to go back to reconfigure the contract.

Experience between competing agents can oftentimes be the determining factor in offers of the same price. If a buyer is looking at identical contracts between a brand-new agent and one with 15+ years of experience, they’ll most likely choose the one with more experience. If you’re the brand-new agent, how do you compete with that? One way is to straight-up call the listing agent and be honest with your newness, how hard you’ve been working with your broker, and how eager you are to close the deal. This can reassure the listing agent because, above all, they want to pick a contract that’s going to close.

These are just some of the tricks that will help you get your offer accepted. If you have any other questions or are interested in listing homes, please give me a call or shoot me an email. I’m looking for one team member that wants to make $150,000 as a listing partner. Have an awesome week!

link.title: How To Win Multiple Offer Situations for Your Buyer

entry.title: The Script We Use for Success
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com

I hope you are absolutely killing it in today’s market. I was just looking at some numbers and my team has had one of the best weeks we’ve ever had. In fact, we are carrying 85 pending transactions! I have agents selling four homes a week. One agent even sold five in one day!

You might be wondering how we are able to get this much volume. The real money is not in just generating leads. A monkey can generate 2,000 leads a month from the internet. The real money is in conversion. How are you converting those leads?

We have been coaching with Corcoran Group Consulting, and their systems work. We follow their LPMAMA script. LPMAMA stands for location, price, motivation, agent, mortgage, and appointment. This is the script my agents use to call their leads, and many of them have 13 buyers ready to purchase in the next 30 days. What can you do with 13 buyers? Think about that.

Now, let’s run through the LPMAMA script:

  • Location: Ask the buyer where they are looking. Do they have kids? Which schools are they interested in? Where do they work? What kind of commute do they want?
  • Price: What price range can they afford? Do they even know what they can afford?
  • Motivation: Are the buyers in a lease? Are they relocating? What is their timeframe? Motivation is the most important factor - depending on a buyer’s situation, you may need to really hit the ground running.
  • Agent: Are you working with an agent? Before we started coaching, I can’t tell you how many times one of our agents showed up at a property to meet a buyer only to discover that the buyer already has an agent.
  • Mortgage: Are they approved? You can say something like, “The last thing I want is for you to fall in love with a home you cannot afford. Let me get you in touch with our mortgage broker to get you a no cost, no obligation pre-approval.”
  • Appointment: Most buyers may want to meet you at the property. Simply ask them to come into your office for a quick buyer consultation so you can find the best home for them and save them time and money.

That’s how we have 85 pending deals right now. If you have any questions about our systems, give us a call or send us an email. I would love to meet up for coffee with you and answer any questions you may have.

link.title: The Script We Use for Success

entry.title: Are You Getting Referrals from Past Clients?
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com

In the last month, I’ve received 12 referrals from past clients. That’s three every single week! If you don’t have a system in place to capture these referrals, then you could be missing out on a huge chunk of business. Today I’ll share some of the things that we do in order to capture these leads.

One way we accomplish this goal is by staying in constant contact with them. We send newsletters, thank-you cards, emails, and even a few free movie tickets every once in awhile. Another cheap and effective thing to do is to call Dunkin Donuts and put your brand on a gift card. They only cost about 80 cents a pop and they’re pretty effective. We’ll also lend out our bounce house occasionally. The key is to just stay in contact with them!


In other news - we’re looking for a new listing partner, and we will provide all of the listings. All you have to do is go on listing appointments. Our top listing partner made $200,000 last year and you can certainly do the same. We’re also looking for a new buyer’s agent if you know anyone that might be interested or qualified.

Last but not least - enjoy the new Barbara Corcoran commercial. You’re the first to see it!

entry.title: How to Make Sure Your Clients' Properties Appraise
entry.content:
Buying a home? Click here to perform a full home search
Selling a home? Click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation 
Call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation

I had a great meeting with the guys from Zillow, who spent three hours in my office recently. They've got some great things going on, so if you're interested in what's going on and how Zillow is changing the industry, please give me a call and let's go out for a cup of coffee.

Today though, I wanted to talk about why we are paid so much: we are paid not to sell real estate, but to solve problems. How many times do you have problems with a transaction? I've closed on 107 homes this year and I've got 68 pending transactions right now, and I'd say 15 to 20 of them have some problems that we're going to have to work through.

One of the main problems I'm seeing is what to do when an appraisal comes in low. Why are they coming in low? I've actually been a licensed appraiser for 20 years, and I know that appraisers are overworked, tired, may not be familiar with the market, and for the most part have never sold real estate. It's one of my pet peeves; I think New York State should require you to sell real estate for several years to be an appraiser, just to understand how the interaction of buyers and sellers happens.

Look at my career - in the early 90s, I started off working as an appraiser, and within a month of starting, I was out telling banks what a house was worth. I had no clue what I was doing then! Luckily I do now, but oftentimes that's the case; they're overworked and not familiar with an area. When the market starts to improve, they're looking at sales from six to 12 months ago, and it's very difficult. With the banking meltdown, appraisers have become risk averse in my opinion.

They look at comparables in a development and they're reluctant to value homes at the highest price in the development. They like to bracket homes. Just recently I saw a deal that was $10,000 over the list price with $10,000 in concessions. That's a really hard deal for an appraiser to appraise. Generally, if you can, do not structure deals over the list price; it defies logic. Unless you have multiple offers in the first week and you can show the appraiser that the price is bid up, you're going to have problems.

So the question then becomes: How do you get your homes to appraise? When I used to be an appraiser, Realtors would bring me comparables. In the back of my mind, I wondered what they were worried about. "Why is this home not going to appraise?" So you want to be careful when providing comparables to appraisers because it can make them wonder what's wrong with the property. My suggestion is to make the process as easy for them as possible - get them the contract as quickly as possible, send them the comparables if they want them, and get them in the house as soon as possible. Remember, they're overworked. Be proactive and use your CMA.



If I can ever help you with anything in your career, give me a call on my direct line!

link.title: How to Make Sure Your Clients' Properties Appraise

entry.title: Why Zillow Is So Important in the Real Estate Industry
entry.content:
Buying a home? Click here to perform a full home search
Selling a home? Click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation 
Call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation

This week, Zillow is flying me out to San Antonio to spend time with their executive team, meet their CEO, and share some ideas. I’m so thrilled for this opportunity! Zillow is a great company, but many people in our industry love to hate Zillow. Today, I’d like to address this concern.

I don’t understand why Zillow receives so much negative attention in the real estate industry. Everyone loves to say that Zestimates are off by 7% to 10%. I think the average Realtor’s list price is off by even more than that. I took over a listing this week and my list price was 33% below the market analysis that the previous Realtor had done. 

You can complain about Zillow all day, but our industry is constantly changing, and we need to embrace sites like Zillow and Trulia.  It wasn’t long ago that travel agents were saying no one would use Travelocity or Expedia, but those two sites have taken over the travel industry.

Zillow brings some tremendous changes to our industry. The days of flyer boxes, just listed or just sold postcards, and open houses are nearly over. We sold 260 homes last year and I think we only did only two open houses for properties that specifically needed them. You can keep doing open houses if you want, but my agents would rather have a buyer in the car who will make a purchase in the next 30 days or go on listing appointments. 

Zillow is changing our industry and I’m sure I’m going to come back with some great ideas. I want to point something out about online leads. I know that Gary Keller recently said something along the lines of, “Your online lead return is -38%.” I couldn’t disagree more with that statement. 


Online leads are important. Zillow is important. If you buy online leads, that’s one important aspect of your lead generation. It’s just one more source to fill your funnel with an unending supply of leads, and you can never have too many leads for your business. 

Open your eyes and see that the real estate industry is shifting. If you have any questions about today’s video or if you are interested in joining our team, just give me a call or send me an email. I look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: Why Zillow Is So Important in the Real Estate Industry

entry.title: Set Standards for Yourself and Your Clients
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Today, I want to talk about standards. I was at a Tony Robbins event a few years ago, and he said, “If you want to change your life, change your standards.”


Our industry is self-policing. You may have a team or manager who sets standards, but it’s up to you to meet them. I recently took over a listing, and quite frankly, it was embarrassing. The prior listing agent had only posted one picture of the front of the property on the MLS. Buyers couldn’t see the interior of the home. The picture wasn’t in high definition, either.

What are your standards for your clients, for your listings? I closed the home this week. Our commission was $30,000. Do you think that my client would be satisfied if I just put one picture of the home on the MLS? No. We shot high definition video tours, used a drone, and utilized extensive advertising to reach higher-end clients for that home.

What are your standards? What are you willing to accept in your life and in your career? We are paid remarkably well in this position, and we need to set a standard of what we’re willing to accept. On my team, every single one of our listings is handled with the same standards.

Are you bringing in a home stager? Are you using professional photography? What are you doing to market the home besides putting the property on the MLS? These are just a few standards you can set for yourself in order to have a successful career.

The standards that you set for yourself and your clients directly affect your career and the number of homes you sell. If you have any questions, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

link.title: Set Standards for Yourself and Your Clients

entry.title: The Simple Truth Behind Making Six Figures
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

In the real estate industry, everybody wants a quick fix. Many agents are always on the lookout for the next shiny object that promises to help them take their business to the next level. For those of you who think there is an easy way to take your company to $50 million a year, I have some bad news. There is no quick fix for your business! 

My advice? Stop chasing squirrels and focus on your skills. Your leads don’t suck, your lead conversion systems suck! I don’t like to talk that way, but sometimes it’s the best way to discuss hard truths. Leads are leads, and if you learn to work them and stick to it, you will find the success you desire. A good agent will put good systems in place and work them until they get results. Jumping around from platform to platform, trying new things every month, will only slow you down.


An agent on my team just recently got her license, and she ALREADY has two homes under contract and six buyers she’s worked with. How does that happen? Well, it’s because she works on her skills, she’s coachable, and she does what we as a team tell her to! We have experience in the industry, so we know what works! All she has to do is contribute her skills to the systems we have in place to find success! She’s on track to do 25 transactions in her first year!

My goal is to get everyone on my team to make over $100,000. We help them to achieve this by giving them the tools to work on their skills. Rather than buying seller leads and trying every new shiny system that comes up, we get down to business and work on our skills! This saves us time and makes us money! 

I hope you find this information helpful. If you want to talk about joining a team or if you’d like to take a look at our scripts, don’t hesitate to reach out to me. I would love to help you make six figures this year!

link.title: The Simple Truth Behind Making Six Figures

entry.title: Being a Phony Will Cost Your Business Clients and Money
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

An interesting thing happened the other day. I overheard an agent in my office take a call from a couple who was moving in from Texas. They weren’t happy with their Realtor, so they reached out to us after hearing a radio ad. They called one of my agents and that agent converted that lead and is now working with that buyer, a $300,000 client! 

Before hiring us, this couple had an agent they had found on the Internet. That agent used Facetime and videos to show them homes in the area. Unfortunately, the agent showed them a home with a floorplan that just didn’t work for the family for a number of reasons. The couple decided to test the agent by asking him what they thought of the place. On cue, the agent said, “This house is amazing! You better make an offer on it because it’s not going to last!” It was then that the family knew they had to find a more trustworthy, less phony, agent. 

The takeaway? That agent lost the buyer client for not being authentic.


If you are going to be in the real estate business, you need to be an expert and create massive value for your clients, whether it’s on the buying or selling side. On the buying side, when the market is this hot, authenticity is one of the most important traits as a young Realtor. Some of the most powerful things you can tell a client are the truth; you can’t be afraid to tell them a house is a piece of junk.

We are expert consultants who create value for clients. You don’t want to put your clients in a home that doesn’t suit their needs. It’s not how you build a business, it’s not the way you build a career, and it’s not the way you build a referral base. You build those things by doing a really good job for each client by using your expertise. 

The lesson today is pretty simple: Don’t be a phony!

If you’ve ever thought about joining a team and are curious about what it’s like to have an endless supply of leads coming in, please don’t hesitate to reach out to me. I would love to chat on the phone or over a cup of coffee about your business. I’d be happy to meet at any time!

link.title: Being a Phony Will Cost Your Business Clients and Money

entry.title: What’s the Key to Running a Successful Brokerage?
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

I hope you are all crushing it so far in 2016. Our team had a great month of January, with 28 closed sales worth $5.5 million.

Today I want to talk about my recent trip to Toronto for the Craig Proctor seminar. I had a lot of takeaways from this event, but I wanted to talk about one in particular. Craig asked the audience what the biggest thing holding them back was from growing their business. There were a lot of different answers, but what Craig said is that it’s your real estate license that is holding you back.

I could not agree more. When I think of people like Lars Hedenborg, Chris Tamm, and others who are selling thousands of homes per year, they all have one thing in common: They stepped out of their business very early-on. These guys aren’t going on listing appointments with buyers, but they are selling over 1000 homes per year.


Getting caught up in the day-to-day of your business is very easy to do. I am unique in that I actually enjoy going out on appointments and meeting with people. However, the idea is to run your real estate business like a business, and that’s something not all of us do.

What you want is a business that will run without you. I’m heading up to New Hampshire for a few days to go skiing, but my team will still be here with boots on the ground in Albany, selling homes. 

Start working on your business this year instead of working in it. I take time every week to go to the library, take notes, and think about what I need to be working on for my business’ continued success. That’s the way to build the wealth and lifestyle you deserve.

If you have any questions, or are curious about joining a team, let me know. We have an endless stream of leads, and are looking for talented individuals who want to take things to the next level. Give me a call or send me an email today!

link.title: What’s the Key to Running a Successful Brokerage?

entry.title: Where Is Your Real Estate Business Headed in 2016?
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Happy New Year! We had an absolutely fantastic 2015. Thank you to everyone who co-brokered a property with us. My team ended the year with 260 home sales and $53 million in volume. My hat's off to the team; they absolutely crushed it this year.

I recently returned from a Mastermind in the Bahamas and a meeting at the ESPN headquarters with Mike and Mike. I'm set to carry that great momentum into 2016. If you haven't already, now is a great time to plan your goals and to make changes going forward. This week, I want you to ask yourself, "What are you going to do differently in 2016 to achieve different results?"

Today, I'm wearing my Susan Coleman tie in respect for all cancer patients. We do all we can to support them. The tie reminds me that if you have your health and the opportunity to make choices, you have an obligation to be the best Realtor you can be.

So, what are you going to do to become the best Realtor you can be in 2016? At the Mastermind, I sat next to a great guy, Chris Tamm. Chris sold his company for several million dollars and he's starting a CRM business. He's a smart guy, and he said, "The seventh level of Keller Williams is not for everyone."

The seventh level of Keller Williams involves stepping out of an active role in your business and letting the team run it. When Chris explained that, it made sense. Maybe you don't want to build a huge team. Maybe it's just you, but you want to get ten more transactions a year. Maybe you only want a small team with an assistant and a listing agent.

There are different models for everyone. This year, cement the vision for what you want to do. Do you want a team? What can you do differently this year to make that vision happen?


Think about the vision you have for your business. Find the model that works for you. If you do nothing else, hop on a plane and surround yourself with greatness. The Bahamas Mastermind was superb. There were forty successful professionals with the same goals learning from each other. That's where you really grow in real estate.


If you have any questions for me, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

entry.title: Why Is the Number of Transactions You Do an Overrated Metric?
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

I'm fresh back from an eventful week in Dallas, where I sat on a panel with some of the best agents from around the country. It was a fantastic experience with a lot of takeaways.

The underlying theme of the week was (in order to have great success) that you need to have clarity on what you want, focus on what it's going to take to get there, and take massive action to make it happen. If you're new to the industry, or even if you've been in it for a while but can't seem to take your business to the next level, that simple theme is something the most successful agents and coaches harp on over and over again.

I was privileged enough to get a chance to speak with Chad Goldwasser, a great motivational speaker and a former KW agent who was the number 1 agent worldwide for that company with $4.7 million GCI with 120 agents underneath him. Talking with Chad and hearing what he had to say, it became clear that he built a massive business with limited upside and return for him. The way he talks about it, it sounds like he wouldn't want to do it again - it was too transitional.

Contrast Chad's experience with that of Mark Burlingame, a friend and great guy I was privileged to know well. He didn't have the most transactions, he wasn't the most powerful broker, but he was rich beyond belief in relationships. When you look at your business, at the end of your career, do you want to see it as built on transactions or relationships? Do you value the lifetime value of a client or are you more concerned with one-and-done transactions just to put numbers up on the board? In other words, what kind of business do you want to be and why?


Our team is focused on relationships first and foremost. The number of transactions we do means less than the number of lives we touch in a meaningful manner. Regardless of the business model you use, I think the best possible use of your time and talents is relationship-building; if you focus on people first, the transactions will follow.

 This was just a quick thought I felt compelled to share. If you have questions about how you can use your real estate business as a means to connect with people, don't hesitate to reach out. I love talking about this stuff and would love to help!

link.title: Why Is the Number of Transactions You Do an Overrated Metric?

entry.title: Be Successful in Real Estate
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Today, I want to talk to you about my experience last week. I went to New York City and spent a day with Barbara Corcoran shooting a new commercial, which should be out in about a month.

Barbara is very humble about her success, and she is really a great person. One thing she said really stuck with me: "Always surround yourself with great people." She says that's the key to her success.

This advice really struck me. For example, I graduated with a marketing degree, got an MBA, and was working in banking when my entire division got wiped out. In eight years, I've built a real estate business. We've been able to go from zero to $50 million in sales, and that's not me. That's my team. I surround myself with incredibly talented people who do a fantastic job for our clients, and I couldn't be more blessed to have this team around me.


When you're buying or selling real estate, it's the same thing. You can sell your home by yourself. You can buy a home by yourself, or use one of those new sites that allows you to just Facetime an agent, tour a home, and pay the commission via rebate. I couldn't disagree with that method more.

You need to surround yourself with professionals. Consumers squander hundreds of millions of dollars every year in the real estate process by hiring inexperienced agents or trying to do things on their own. Whether it's my team or not, you need experienced professionals. We've done this enough times that it's second nature. We close hundreds of deals a year, so we just know what to do in any given situation.


If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to reach out to me. I would be happy to help you.

entry.title: What Is the Key to Barbara Corcoran's Success?
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

I want to talk briefly about a great opportunity I had recently to go down to New York City to spend the day with Barbara Corcoran - it's always a pleasure to be with her. I never want to be the smartest guys in the room - it's rare that I ever am anyway - but when Barbara is around I am far from it!

It was a great opportunity to thank her. Our business is up $12 million or so year-to-date. She said one thing to me that really struck home: "Treat your clients like family, have fun, and everything else falls into place." Think about what that means; it means you need to do a fantastic job for them, make the experience enjoyable for them and yourself, and everything falls into place after that!


How hard do we make real estate sometimes, with all the shiny new gimmicks and things we throw money at to generate leads and grow our business? When you boil it down, it's all about creating a great client experience, treating them well, and letting everything fall into place. Disney has a saying, "Get to the fun FAST," a great mission statement that rings true in all industries. If you're working with first-time buyers, finding a home should be fun! If you're working with an older couple who is looking to downsize, helping them find that new home should be an enjoyable experience for them! You have control over the experience your clients have - so it's crucial you help them to have fun and enjoy the experience.


Barbara built her $64 million business on that simple philosophy, so it's worth thinking about. If you have any questions or would like guidance in building your business, please don't hesitate to reach out out me. I would love to give you a hand in any way possible!

link.title: What Is the Key to Barbara Corcoran's Success?

entry.title: Build a Big Business with a Small Budget
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Today I want to bring you more value and in doing so I also wanted to speak about how you can 'crush it' even with a limited budget in your business.

I recently got back from the real estate trade show, and everyone wanted to know what it was like working with Barbara Corcoran. However, after a while I noticed that everyone I spoke with was trying to tell me that they didn't have the money to spend on marketing with Barbara Corcoran.


I want to put the rumors aside, because I didn't spend $50,000 or $60,000 to shoot the commercials with her. I'm going to New York again, and I'm actually only spending $1,600 to shoot another commercial with her. I was fortunate enough to be invited by her team while they used the studio.

So, if you don't have the ability to work with Barbara, how should you compete?

I think Chris Smith hit the nail on the head with this one when he said that service is marketing. If you have no budget, then let your service sell itself. When your business is smaller, you have the ability to interact with each and every one of your clients. People enjoy that - and that's something I can't do anymore. I just don't have time to see everyone.

The edge that you have as a smaller company or team is that you have more time to devote to your clients. You can put more energy into your introductions, into your goodbyes, and into maintaining those relationships down the line. I have too many clients to remember all of their names and their kids' names. One trick I recommend is to write them a handwritten note after every transaction (which we actually still do to this day).

All in all, you have the opportunity right now to show your clients how much you care about them. Shake your clients' hands. Hug them. Talk to them. Just show them that you care! Make your service personable and memorable and they will come back to you!


As always, please don't hesitate to reach out to me with any questions or concerns!

link.title: Build a Big Business with a Small Budget

entry.title: The #1 Thing to Focus on in Your Real Estate Business
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.


Today I have some exciting news for you. I've been invited to speak at a conference in Dallas, and I've been scheduled to talk on the last day about my marketing plans. I'll be competing for marketer of the year, and while I'm a little nervous to present my marketing plans to over 500 people, I know that I can't grow while staying in my comfort zone.

Speaking of marketing, lets take a moment to discuss marketing, because a lot of people can confuse it with advertising. There are four pillars of marketing, and they are product, place, price, and promotion. Today I want to talk about the product in more detail.


In an industry like real estate, you need to be able to sell yourself as a product. You need to have your skills ready to go when that promotion kicks in. I recently went on a listing with five other agents, and I was chosen over them because I knew how to answer the tough questions. I told this seller everything I knew about the market, and that won me the listing. I was able to sell myself and my product, and that's what I always focus on first. Place all of your energy into your product before you start developing your other P's.

If you have any questions about how you can develop and refine your product, I'd love to sit down and share a cup of coffee with you.

I look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: The #1 Thing to Focus on in Your Real Estate Business

Today I just wanted to talk about an observation that I made in the past few days. I've had multiple agents come into my office after starting their own firms, and they're at a loss for who to call to speak about leads. They've exhausted their databases and their contacts. They didn't know who else to call for leads.

One thing that I resent about this industry is that it's been taken over by large, Fortune 500 firms that sell leads back to us. I'm not a fan of this, but sometimes you must play by the rules that the industry creates.


Referrals alone are probably not enough for you, so at some point you may need to pay for your leads. I spend nearly $100,000 per year in order to gather leads. This gets me quite a lot of leads, and I depend on my team to follow up on them.

This is also why it's essential to be working with a team in our industry. As a single agent, you just can't respond to leads as quickly as you need to.

If you're struggling as a single agent, please don't hesitate to reach out to me. We're always looking for good people to join our team. If you have any questions about an opportunity here at Clancy Real Estate, please don't hesitate to contact me!

entry.title: Are You Truly Committed to Your Real Estate Career?
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Today, I want to share some insights with you, particularly if you are making under six figures in your career. There was a time when I struggled immensely in my career, and I wondered if I had made the correct choice. Ultimately, I made an absolute commitment to be successful in my career.

We all have fears. I was afraid of heights, and I made it a point to face my fears. Skydiving helped me realize that my fear of heights was just not rational. As the plane approached jump height, I was petrified. But once I jumped, I became totally relaxed.


Why did that happen? Because once I was in the air, I was committed. The entire plane ride up, I had the option to back out. It's the same with real estate. Once you commit to it, things change.

I really believe that the key to success in real estate is commitment. Commit to excellence, to learning something every day, and to doing a great job for your clients. That's how you get the $20,000 commission check every week. There's no point in dabbling in this business. You need to be all in.

 If you have any questions, please give me a call or send me an email. I'd be happy to offer further guidance.

entry.title: Why Do Agents Struggle?
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Why do agents struggle? Why do you get out of bed in the morning? Why are you working in real estate?

I want to share a quick story with you that I've heard from some of my mentors. It's the story of Cortez conquering Mexico. Other conquistadors had tried but failed. When Cortez landed, he had his men burn their boats. They couldn't retreat, so they had no choice to conquer Mexico. And they did!


This proves a good point: your "why" needs to be big enough that it makes you get out of bed with excitement. What is your "why"? What gets you motivated? What do you need to accomplish?

I've been very fortunate in my career and my "why" has changed over time. Initially, it was to give my kids a good life. Now that they are set, my "why" is to help my agents meet their goals, help my clients meet their goals, and to give to charity.

 So this week, think about why you do what you do. Find something that makes you excited to get out of bed and get to work. If you have any questions, please give me a call or send me an email. I'd be happy to help you.

entry.title: How Can Creating Massive Value for Clients Help You Grow Your Business?
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Recently, I was lucky enough to have a conversation with Kevin O'Leary and Barbara Corcoran of Shark Tank about what it takes to create a successful business. Today, I want to share what they shared with me.

The number one thing they said you should focus on to grow your business is creating massive value. The goal is to create massive value for your clients! We're in an industry that, very likely, may go the way of travel agents. If we are not careful, if we don't go above and beyond when working with clients, websites like Zillow and Trulia are going to put us out of business.


The days of big commission checks and fees are going to go by the wayside unless we create massive value. To do this, you need to strive every day to be an expert. Knowing your numbers and staying in close contact with the client are both signs that you're not only a serious professional, but an expert who offers value that can't be found anywhere else! You want to end every deal knowing you got the best possible price for your client and that you care about them.

People don't care how much you know until they know how much you care. Treat your clients like family and make sure they are happy with your services. In fact, if a client comes to the closing table unhappy, I will write them the commission check back! We then go back and forensically reconstruct what we did wrong and what we could have done differently to get a better result!

If you have questions about how you can add value to your services and your business, give me a call. I'm always available to help you build your business!

entry.title: How I Was Voted the #1 Realtor in Albany
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

A few years ago I was voted in as the #1 Realtor in the Times Union here in Albany. This competition only took place once, but I'm going to tell the story today.

One morning I was sitting in on a City Council meeting and I started getting messages congratulating me for winning this award. I didn't even know the competition was happening, and this was before I started doing radio or television.


The reason that I won was quite simple. I was active in a lot of business groups, and I was constantly meeting people. I'd accumulate hundreds of business cards at the end of each month, and that went the same way for many other people. 

So, I was meeting people, but not really forming relationships. In order to deepen my contact with these people - whom I had maybe spoken to for 10 minutes, I started writing a Monday Morning MOJO email. 

I put every single business card into my database, and in my Monday Morning MOJO email, I would talk about something valuable. I talked about my family, my fears, or even about the time that I went skydiving. 

What happened was that people became comfortable with me, and I was at the top of their mind when they were asked about the best Realtor in Albany. 

Essentially, my database allowed me to grow my real estate business. It was very simple, and very cost effective. It took a lot of time to grow my database, but it was well worth the effort.

As always, if you're interested in joining my team, please call me. I'm always looking for good people and I would love to speak with you. I want nothing more than for you to make six figures selling real estate this year. 

Make it a good one!

link.title: How I Was Voted the #1 Realtor in Albany

entry.title: What Does It Take to Be Successful?
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Hey everyone, thanks for joining me today. I want to answer a question that I've been getting a lot lately. Our team has been lucky to be very successful in the real estate world, and people are wondering what makes us successful. Today I want to tell you a little bit about me and why I have succeeded in real estate. 



Only a few short years ago, I was unemployed and struggling to support my family. I sat down and wrote down what I wanted in life and what I was willing to give up for it. Since then, I have surrounded myself with and tried to learn from the best, and my goal is to always strive to be better. 

It's easy to stay even with the pack and enjoy mild success. It's very difficult to struggle, to fail, and get back up again. When you are used to winning in life, you're going to get complacent when you realize there is always someone out there working harder than you. 

I ran cross country in high school, but didn't have a lot of natural ability. Every day after school, I would run a grueling 1.5 miles up a steep hill. There is nothing harder to do, but the dedication made me a better runner and allowed me to compete at a higher level. I kept working at it, and didn't let my failures indicate my future performance. 

Succeeding in anything comes down to hard work and sacrifice. It's not easy to succeed in life, but you can as long as you learn from your failures, and persevere through them. It's always darkest before the dawn. 

If you have any questions for us, or if we can help you in any way, give me a call or send me an email. If you're struggling, I'd be glad to give you some advice on how you can turn things around. I look forward to speaking with you soon!

link.title: What Does It Take to Be Successful?

entry.title: Advice from the Sharks: Know Your Numbers!
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

I was recently able to attend a mastermind in San Diego, and I had a great time. All the big players in the real estate world were there, including Barbara Corcoran and Kevin O'Leary, AKA Mr. Wonderful.  They talked to us about the contestants that win on the show, and what they have in common. Here are the three things that they shared with us that the winners have in common:

1. They are able to articulate the opportunity in 90 seconds or less.
2. They are successful in convincing investors that they are the right team to execute the business plan.
3. They know their numbers inside and out and have a comprehensive understanding of their business models.



This advice actually translates pretty well when talking about listing presentations. Here are 3 things you need to do in every listing presentation:

1. You've got to convey the benefits of working with you.
2. You've got to convey that you're the right person for the job by expressing it in the right way.
3. You better know your numbers inside and out (list-to-sale ratio, median home prices, absorption rates, etc.).

This will likely be one of the largest investments that a person will make. Ensuring you do these 3 things will ensure your success on listing presentations. 

If you have any questions, or would like to consider joining my team, give us a call or send us an email. My goal is to have all of my agents making 6 figures, and we are well on our way to accomplishing that.

entry.title: How Can You Sell 100% of Your Listings?
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Welcome back to my coaching blog. I always get asked the question, "Are you practicing what you're preaching, and are the things you talk about working in your business?" Yes we are, and yes they do work. So far this year, we are at 132 closed transactions and have received 68 seller requests in the last week alone. 



I recently visited San Diego and got to attend an awesome mastermind. All the big players in the business were there, including Gary Keller, Jay Kinder, and Shark Tank's own Barbara Corcoran and Kevin O'Leary.

The potential in this industry is huge if you apply yourself, so I wanted to share with you some of the takeaways I got from this mastermind. If you are not selling 100% of your listings right now, listen to this. A friend of mine named Jason Bramblett sells 100% of his listings, and here is how he does it: 

He requires the sellers to come to his office, so that automatically weeds out the unmotivated sellers. He then requires them to pay for an appraisal, a home inspection and home staging if necessary. By doing these things, he knows exactly where to price the home so it sells the fastest and for the most money possible. He may be listing a smaller group of homes, but he is selling them all. He doesn't have any expired listings. 

You may be skeptical, but I think if you wrap your head around it and apply this type of process to your home sellers, you'll see how effective of a strategy it could be. 

If you have any questions for us, we would be glad to answer them. Just give me a call or send me an email. I look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: What Two Traits Does Every Successful Person Have?
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Today, I want to share two things I know you'll find helpful. First, I want to share a talking point about our low inventory you can discuss with potential clients. Then, I want to share two traits that all successful people have, whether they are Realtors, doctors, CEOs, or investment bankers. Let's jump right in!

Many people in the industry are claiming that inventory is very low right now because of the severe winter we had in the Albany area. To me, this couldn't be further from the truth. My training tells me that low inventory is the result of the fact that real estate markets run in 7-8 year cycles. This current cycle started around 2007, and we're clearly due for an upswing. 

According to the NAR, people move every 7-8 years on average. So, when looking at the people who should be interested in purchasing a home right now, it's likely they bought their current home in 2006 or 2007. If they didn't put much money down, they have little or no equity in their home right now! In the last two weeks, we've had 63 people contact us who want to sell their homes. Of those people, around 25 of them had no equity in their home and can't sell; this is the reason inventory is low, not the harsh winter.

When working with buying clients, explain to them where we're at in the current cycle. A lot of people who should be looking to list their home at this time have little or no equity, so they're waiting to sell. This has led to a tighter market, in which buyers are having trouble finding a great home. Telling them the low inventory is a result of a harsh winter is going to give them the idea the inventory will rise as the weather begins to improve, which simply isn't the case. 

Now, on to some more positive news. At the end of the week, I'm lucky to be going to a mastermind in San Diego. Kevin O'Leary from Shark Tank and Keller Williams CEO Chris Heller will both be there, so I will CERTAINLY not be the smartest guy in the room. I hope to get some interviews with those guys and other top real estate minds from around the country, so I can share what I learn with you right here on this blog.

What I learned last year at this mastermind with these folks is that all successful people have 2 traits: 
  1. Self-awareness: This has to do with how you fit in and how you are perceived by other people. It's how you view your place in the world and how those around you view you.
  2. Authenticity: This one is the most important. Be who you are and call it like it is; don't try to sell anyone a bag of goods they have no business buying. Be real and you'll find it not only makes you more comfortable, but more successful. 
If you focus on these two traits, you'll be one step closer to success. For more tips and tricks to help grow your business and take your career to the next level, give me a call or shoot me an email. I'm always available to talk.

link.title: What Two Traits Does Every Successful Person Have?

entry.title: The Secret to Marketing Your Listings
entry.content:
Looking to improve your real estate career? I'm here to help you make a smart decision when it comes to growing your business, improving your bottom line, and choosing a place to work in real estate sales. If you'd like to learn more about working with Clancy Real Estate, contact me at (518) 861-7016 or Kevin@ClancyRealEstate.com.

Hello, and thanks for joining me today! I know your time is important, so thank you for spending it with us!

Most of the coaching programs I've been involved in are focused on "getting the listing." They spend a whole lot less time teaching how to actually market a home and what the systems and processes are to get the home sold once it's on the market. 

Today, I want to talk about the use of flyer boxes in front of the listing. In my opinion, they are a complete waste of time! 

A few months ago I had a $600,000 listing that had expired with two top agents in the past. They had flyers in the house and in front of the house that were professionally done and of a high quality, but they clearly didn't work. 

I haven't used property flyers for 2-3 years. When I talked to the agents who failed to sell the above listing, they said they had only handed out 5 brochures because they only had 5 showings. Here's the problem: people are only seeing flyers once they're in the house. As an agent, your job is to drive traffic to get people in the house in the first place - not to make fancy brochures and  just hope people show up!

We use an 800 number now, and we highly recommend giving it a try. If you put a flyer in front of your listing, you have no way of knowing if and when a buyer takes one. If you put a phone number for a call capture system outside the house, you will be instantly notified when a buyer calls it. You will have access to the callers' names and sometimes even their current addresses! 

This is a more effective and more trackable way of gauging interest in your listings. Instead of using the old-school technique of flyers, put an 800 call capture system in front of your house! We think you'll see some fantastic results.

If you have any questions about this topic, or if you're looking to work with a better team, give me a call or shoot me an email. I would love to hear from you!

link.title: The Secret to Marketing Your Listings
